North Melbourne legend David King has praised the Western Bulldogs for having the ‘biggest premiership window’ in the competition, but criticised their inability to land an experienced ruckman during the trade period.

Despite an impressive run to the Grand Final, the Bulldogs’ ruck department was widely considered their biggest weakness in 2021.

Injuries restricted veteran recruit Stefan Martin to nine games, while Tim English showed he wasn’t ready to shoulder the load, with the club at times deploying defender Lewis Young as a makeshift ruck over him.

The Dogs were reportedly in the market for a ruckman over the exchange period, but the likes of Jonathon Ceglar (traded from Hawthorn to Geelong) and Peter Ladhams (traded from Port Adelaide to Sydney) moved elsewhere.

Tim English competing against Luke Jackson in the Grand Final (Photo by Will Russell/AFL Photos via Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

Speaking on Fox Footy’s Trading Day, King questioned why the Dogs didn’t prioritise acquiring a gun big man.

“I really worry about the fact that they haven’t gone after a ruckman. They’ve got the midfield, they’ve got everything there. I just don’t know why they didn’t take the risk using a future pick if it had to be to get an established ruckman,” the dual premiership Kangaroo said.

“Someone like (Todd) Goldstein or can you pry a Brodie Grundy? You’re in there now and I know they’re going to be in this window for a long period of time. So I don’t think one or two draft picks over the next couple of years would seriously impact what this group is going to be able to do for I think six to eight years.”

Herald Sun reporter Jon Ralph highlighted that Ladhams’ management made contact with the Bulldogs, but the club’s need to retain draft points to match an early bid on father-son prodigy Sam Darcy limited its capacity to broker a trade.

King believes the Bulldogs have to maximise their window of opportunity with the current list and deliver more silverware.

“They’ve got the biggest window of anyone in the competition right now,” he said.

“If they don’t win two premierships in the next six years, it’s a blown opportunity. When you get the list build to correct like this, this is what it afford you, a sustained opportunity.

“If you asked all 18 coaches which group they’d love to get their hands on, I reckon the Dogs would come out favourably.”



St Kilda champion Leigh Montagna thinks the Bulldogs are backing in the natural improvement of English and Jordon Sweet to make them more competitive in the ruck.

“They were 19 points up in the third quarter of the Grand Final, you give Tim English and Jordon Sweet another 12 months and another pre-season to develop, give them a bit of faith and confidence to develop,” he said.

“I think they’ll be OK without that extra ruckman. When you do get in the window, history shows you do get the chance to play in multiple Grand Finals.”

The Bulldogs’ depth took a hit in the trade period through the departures of Young (Carlton) and Patrick Lipinski (Collingwood) to rival clubs.

But they were able to land former Hawk Tim O’Brien as an unrestricted free agent to give their defence a boost, having ranked 14th in the competition in intercept marks in 2021.

O’Brien showed the Dogs first hand how effective he can be in arguably a career-best performance against them in Round 22, gathering 24 disposals, 14 intercepts and six intercept marks with a 24.9 AFL Players Rating – all of which were rated elite by Champion Data.

“I love the Tim O’Brien addition, they really lack for an interceptor down back,” King said.

“If you look at the Grand Final when that ball came out of the middle, they really struggled to win it back.

“O’Brien gives you that versatility, it’s worth the risk at no cost.”

AFL greats Kane Cornes and David King have clashed over the market value of Blues ruckman Tom De Koning after the young gun was omitted from Carlton's senior team for a second straight week.

De Koning was managed for the Blues' 22-point loss to St Kilda and has now been named in Carlton's VFL squad for this weekend's match against West Coast.

The 23-year-old ﻿is unsigned beyond the 2023 season and has two years remaining before he becomes a free agent in 2026.

The hype surrounding De Koning has been building over the past two seasons with the 23-year-old shouldering a majority of the ruck load in a predominantly unsteady Carlton side.

Now, the youngster is being ﻿touted as the pick of the market, with reports of him already attracting big-money offers from Sydney and St Kilda.

Debating the figure on SEN radio, Cornes argued De Koning's skills in the ruck and up forward were highly sought after by rival clubs, which could trigger contracts in the ballpark of $1 million annually.

However, King, who has previously said he's not convinced of De Koning's influence so early into his career, believes that being out of Carlton's team will impact his asking price.

King: "It's hard to sign a player if you're not going to play him."

Cornes: "He's going to have massive offers, I think he will."

Asked if it is wise to skip past offering an adequate, short-term contract, Cornes said De Koning was not worth such a salary but could see it being tabled to lure him away from Ikon Park.

Cornes argued he was worth ﻿"$400,000-450,000 on current form".

"Which means he'll get $600,000," King replied.

King later questioned which past performance from De Koning convinced Cornes that he was worth a monster pay day.

"Can you tell me the game I should go and watch where you saw it?," he said.

To make his point, Cornes ﻿referenced Luke Jackson's move from Melbourne to Fremantle.

Jackson granted Fremantle trade wish

"Everything Luke Jackson does, De Koning does just as well," he said.

"So if Luke Jackson is getting seven years at $900,000 (per season), this is what this guy is going to get, he's going to command that.

"There's a couple of good games in the ruck last year he played, I remember going on the Footy Show after one of them saying this guy will be the next $1 million player."

"Isn't Luke Jackson a cautionary tale?," King added.

"Perhaps, but clubs don't heed cautionary tales, they don't learn. Think of some of the numbers players get – the contract (Dan) McStay gets and the contract Aidan Corr gets. These are big contracts," Cornes said.

"I'm already hearing seven years at Sydney (for De Koning), all the Saints fans are all over him, they want him. He will not be struggling for a mule at the end of this year. He's going to get a big, long-term deal, I'm certain of it.

"I don't know if he'll leave, I'm just saying the offers will be there for him to leave and he'll have a hard choice to make."

Rising Western Bulldogs star Tim English is capable of being the best ruckman in the competition, according to Saints great Nick Dal Santo.

English produced arguably a career-best performance in the Dogs’ 11-point win over Sydney on Thursday night, racking up 24 disposals, 11 contested, seven inside 50s, eight clearances, five tackles and eight marks to finish with a game-high 17.6 player rating points.

What was perhaps most impressive was how English outduelled veteran ruckman Tom Hickey for most of the night prior to the Swans big man exiting the game with a knee injury.

The 24-year old English’s presence around the ground was simply enormous, taking huge grabs – including a highlight intercept mark over Buddy Franklin – and providing valuable support to the midfield, while a crunching bump to Nick Blakey could come under scrutiny from the MRO.

English takes a huge grab over Franklin (Photo by Robert Cianflone/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

Speaking on Fox Footy’s First Crack, Dal Santo lauded English for taking another big step forward in his development.

“This guy is capable of being the No. 1 ruckman in the competition and consistent as anybody in the most brutal position on the ground,” Dal Santo said.

“He was fantastic tonight and his contest against Tom Hickey before he went off injured was a thing of delight.

“My new favourite thing in a game is when a ruckman bounces the ball – he did it twice tonight. He’s a fantastic player.”

English has taken some time to develop, previously playing as a backup ruck/key forward after struggling against the game’s premier ruckmen. It led to the Dogs at times losing ascendancy in the midfield – a key strength area where they’re loaded with stars.

But in 2022 the out of-contract Western Australian has been given full rein as the Bulldogs’ No. 1 ruckman and flourished, averaging career-highs across the board in disposals (22.7 per game), marks (6.7), hitouts (22.3), inside 50s (3.7) and clearances (7.3),

English and Hickey go head to head (Photo by Michael Willson/AFL Photos via Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

Dal Santo believes the well-rounded English is now one of the Bulldogs’ most important players.

“It’s the impact and craft and what you demand of a touch ruckman. It’s the way he’s getting around the ground, his touch by foot, his ability to impact forward when he has more support,” he said.

“They are desperate for someone forward to support, they’ve actually got it, they just need to fill the other pieces. Because you can’t have him in both areas. We take about whether Bont should play midfield or forward? We’ve also got another guy who’s capable of it.”

Triple premiership-winning Cat Cam Mooney highlighted how big men take longer to hit their prime, but that all signs point to English become one of the game’s top ruckman.

“You’re going to have games where you get absolutely embarrassed by Brodie Grundy, but then you’re going to have games where you embarrass a really good ruckman in Hickey,” he said.

“He’s still growing and learning, we know his upside is amazing, but his consistency isn’t there. When it is, he’s going to be a star.”

Bulldogs coach Luke Beveridge was also full of praise for English, labelling it a “dominant” performance.

“That’s important for him and us. He’s been playing the turnover game pretty well and defensively,” he told reporters.

“He’s searching for his presence around the source, he gave us stability. He won the hitout count which is terrific for him and us. Had a big impact on the game.”

Bulldogs skipper Marcus Bontempelli admitted on Fox Footy that English is stick developing his ruck craft, but emphasised how valuable he’s become around the ground.

It reminded North Melbourne legend David King of Melbourne champion Jim Stynes.

“Not necessarily a dominant ruckman, but gets the ball around the ground, he had 12 scoring involvements tonight,” he told Fox Footy post-match.

“He still had the 26 hitouts, but we’re not really judging him on his hitout work, as long as he can break-even, or thereabouts.”



It’s no surprise that the WA clubs are trying to lure English home at season’s end, with West Coast looking for a long-term successor for Nic Naitanui.

Dual premiership Kangaroo David King has detailed an “exposed flaw” in the Western Bulldogs’ game, claiming the absence of an “A-grade ruckman” could cost them dearly in their bid to claim the AFL premiership.

The Bulldogs on Sunday lost just their fifth game of the AFL season, going down to Essendon by 13 points at Marvel Stadium.

While the Dogs won the contested possession count, they lost the clearance count to the Bombers – and by a lot (-16). It was just the fourth time this season the Dogs, who have a star-studded midfield brigade, had lost the clearance battle in a game.

But most alarmingly was the Bombers’ ability to hit the scoreboard from stoppages, booting 11.4 (70) from clearances – clearly the most points the Dogs had conceded from that source this season.

Speaking on Fox Footy’s First Crack, King said those clearance numbers were “frightening” reading for the Dogs, especially consider the Bombers opted to go head-to-head in the midfield and not tag the likes of Marcus Bontempelli, Jack Macare or Tom Liberatore.

King said a big reason behind the Bombers’ stoppage dominance on Sunday was due to Tim English’s inability to impose himself.

Tim English of the Bulldogs and Sam Draper of the Bombers. Picture: Michael Willson Source: Getty Images

With Stefan Martin still sidelined with a groin injury – there’s still little certainty around when, or if, the veteran ruckman will return – and Jordon Sweet not selected, English rucked against Bombers duo Sam Draper and Peter Wright, who had 10 more hitouts-to-advantage than English.

“If you enter September and you haven’t got a bona fide A-grade ruckman, you get exposed,” King told First Crack. “You don’t have to have a guy that shapes the game like Nic Nat, you don’t have to have a Max Gawn, but it’s such an advantage if you do.

“For me, it rings alarm bells about what the Dogs are doing.

“I think we were exposed (on Sunday) to a game that I think would have Luke Beveridge at home tonight thinking: ‘Gee, what’s this going to do to my September campaign?’ Because English, as good as he is around the ground with taking contested marks and getting forward, is not an A-grade ruckman.”

King pointed to Champion Data statistics that showed just how good the Dogs are from clearances.

Across the season, the Dogs are +136 on their opposition for effective clearances, as well as +66 for points from effective clearances. The Bulldogs are also the best team in the league, both frequency and scoring-wise, at handballing the footy out of stoppage.

But King said the stats prove how heavily the Dogs rely upon their stoppage brilliance to win them games, adding Sunday provided evidence that Beveridge’s side can be beaten at the coalface, especially if an opposition team has strong rucks.

Luke Beveridge, senior coach of the Bulldogs. Picture: Michael Willson Source: Getty Images

“Their game is a midfield game … This is their game, this is their identity, this is who they are,” King said of the Dogs.

“When they come out by hand, this is the killer. When they’re able to link and go and run, they put it on the scoreboard, No. 1 in the competition. So as soon as you see Bontempelli and those guys flinging it around, you’re in trouble if you’re the opposition.

“But if they can’t get their hands on the ball or disrupt and win it back from the opposition, they’re in trouble.

“So there’s an exposed flaw there that I think would give Luke Beveridge some sleepless nights.”

IN 2016, Max Gawn established himself as the premier ruckman in the competition.

But now, the Melbourne big man could be set to take his game to another level altogether.

That’s according to Fox Footy analyst David King, who says the AFL banning the use of the “third man up” at ruck contests will give Gawn an extra edge on his competitors this season.

“If you look at him play, he’s a man who’s in complete control of his area,” King said on SEN.

“The rule changes will only assist him this season.

“I think he’s only played 50 or 60 games of AFL football, so he’s still learning.”

Gawn averaged 42.2 hitouts per game in 2016 but crucially, won a hitout from 54 per cent of ruck contests, with a hitout-to-advantage rate of 34 per cent and was the only ruckman Champion Data rated ‘elite’ in these statistics.

But where the ruckman can further add to his game is his work up forward.

Gawn kicked 16 goals in 2016 but was able to kick two or more goals on six occasions, highlighting his potential to push forward.

Max Gawn celebrates after kicking a goal. Source: Getty Images

With the ruckman having played a full season for the first time in his career, King said there was still plenty of improvement in his game.

“I love the use of him during the preseason, how he’s been able to get forward,” he said.

“He hasn’t been a big goal scorer in the past. I think he kicked (close to) 20 goals last season. He’s ready for a huge year.

“I think he understands what’s required and I guess those young mannerisms of 18-months ago are gone. He’s a man now and I think he’s ready to take control of the game.”

If Gawn is to elevate his game to another level, he could well require support in the ruck.

While defender Sam Frost and forward Jack Watts pinch-hit at times in 2016, reserve ruckman Jake Spencer’s fine pre-season has lifted him into the conversation for a senior spot.

In Melbourne’s first JLT Community game against the Bulldogs, Spencer — who last played at AFL level in Round 22, 2015 — recorded 23 hitouts in a solid performance.

“I think when you look at Spencer’s tap work — that has been the one reason you could look at it because he hasn’t let them down,” King said.

“They haven’t dropped off when he’s gone into the absolute ruck in the middle.

“I think with Gawn, his contested marking is something that is understated. We saw him virtually beat Geelong single-handedly a couple of years ago down at the Cattery.”

While Gawn dominated as a lone ruckman in 2016, King said the Demons needed to seriously consider keeping Spencer in the side.

Jake Spencer and Matthew Kreuzer compete for the ball. Source: Getty Images

“I think they could (play both). I don’t think it’s something Simon (Goodwin) would have thought would have been a likely option going into the JLT.

“But they’re almost forced to at this stage. If they have another great performance from their ruckmen in the next (game), I think you’d be loathe to change it going into Round 1.”

Gawn’s ruck dominance gives Melbourne’s young midfield a helping hand heading into a season where it is largely expected to be one of the competition’s big improvers.

The likes of Jack Viney, Angus Brayshaw and Clayton Oliver are all expected to showcase their wares this season, while forward/midfielder Christian Petracca will also spend time in a midfield bolstered by the recruitment of ex-Hawthorn veteran Jordan Lewis.

But King said the Demons needed to show some consistency before they could be listed among the competition’s better midfields.

“I still think that midfield is 20-30 games short of becoming an absolute staple,” he said.

“You talk about Brayshaw a lot, you talk about Petracca, Oliver’s another one you throw up. But we haven’t seen them do it yet across a six or eight week block.

Their patches have been fantastic. But they’re not (star) midfielders yet.

“For me, that’s the only query. But if it comes, like GWS, it will come quickly.”

This season marks the beginning of a new coaching era for Melbourne, now under the guidance of Simon Goodwin.

Dean Kent and Simon Goodwin. Source: News Corp Australia

King said he expected the enthusiasm and standards driven by the ex-Adelaide captain to be reflected in an exciting year on the field for the young Demons.

“I think Simon Goodwin has been an innovator over the last couple of seasons,” King said.

“He finally gets full control. We’ve been really excited by what we’ve seen in the first couple of weeks of the JLT and I just think the growth is going to be enormous for this young group.

“They’ve been told they can seriously play, they’ve been told they need to work hard. They’ve got a club now that’s set some pretty high standards.

“I think it will be a really positive year for them.”

GEELONG coach Chris Scott believes that when it comes to managing ruckmen “you’ve either got too many or not enough. You never get it exactly right”.

With the substitute rule operating in recent seasons, most coaches would admit to having more than the game demanded.

They were once reluctant to play two ruckmen under the substitute conditions and if they did, one of them would invariably finish the game in red.

However, with the return of four interchange players in 2016, some might now be wondering whether they’ve got enough.

Fox Footy analyst David King believes ruckmen will be the greatest beneficiaries of this rule change.

He predicts coaches will select two ruckmen more often and, specifically, to combat a dominant opposition ruckman.

“When you look at the Kangaroos’ advantage over the past few years it’s been Todd Goldstein’s ability to play 90 per cent of game time in the ruck,” he told SEN radio.

“Now there will be an ability to double team him because you can rest a ruckman on the bench.”

King suggested that the cap on rotations would also give coaches greater confidence to play two ruckmen, even if it means playing limited minutes.

“They can rest for longer and you can still spin the bench at the same pace you have over the last couple of years,” he said.

“I think the challenge would be balancing your rucks. Would you go for one, would you go for one and a makeshift? Or, could you go for a bona fide two ruckmen?”

Champion Data analyst Glenn Luff says some clubs might opt to pick two ruckmen if they don’t have the luxury of a competent part-timer.

“It depends if you have a player that can actually play forward-ruck and there’s not many that can play it,” he said.

“We all thought Paddy Ryder could go over to Port and play that forward can go into the ruck, but Paddy is a ruckman then a resting forward.”

Geelong has no such restriction with Zac Smith, Rhys Stanley, Nathan Vardy and Mitch Clark at coach Scott’s disposal.

While, on the flip side, Essendon has just two pure ruckmen on its senior list plus Shaun McKernan, who is likely to fill a key forward role.

“They are all athletic and can play centre-half forward, they can play deep forward, they can run in the ruck and almost be an extra on-baller ... I want to see how they go because they are something unique we haven’t seen before,” King said.

“We just hope that Alastair Clarkson can come back, get his feet under the desk and deliver on what is an unbelievable coaching CV and help build this football club.

King was in Echuca on Tuesday as one of the guests at the Echuca Racecourse’s annual publicans day.

He was invited up by his good friend and renowned football commentator Tony Leonard — who was the MC for the day — and King said he jumped at the opportunity.

The pair have known each other for 20 years, with King commentating alongside Leonard back in the day.

“I’ve known Tony for a long time. When I first came out of footy I worked with 3AW, and Tony was part of the biggest calling team in the game back then with Rex Hunt,” king said.

“I have had a great relationship with Tony for a long period of time. I still think he is the best caller in footy. He is not the best to look at, but he is the best to listen to.”

“They are different to city folk. It is a more cruisy, relaxed atmosphere. Everyone is happy to have a beer and a laugh.”

King was part of North Melbourne’s golden generation in the mid-late 90s, but he said there was a distinctly country footy feel about the AFL club at the time.

“It was like a country football club playing in the AFL, that is how I would describe it,” he said.

“It was great. We were so thick and so tight. The guys went everywhere together — we won together, we lost together. We grew up from teenagers into men, into fathers and husbands, we lived all that together and it was such a great ride.

“The North Melbourne Football Club I know would be the same as the Echuca Football Netball club or any regional club. We were just a good bunch of lads that got on so well.”

The hard-nosed midfielder and defender won two premierships and played in more than a dozen finals throughout his career. But looking back, he said it was a different game that stood out as the most memorable.

“Probably the most special game in my memory would be after the Wayne Carey saga,” he said.

“We went to Port Adelaide 10 days after the Carey story broke, we had to play in round one against Port Adelaide over there, and we won.

A tough, pacy, relentlessly aggressive footballer, he was equally adept in a number of positions, including the wing, a back pocket or half back flank, and ruck-rover.
